Editorial

  • James Ritchie1,
  • Judy Vance2 &
  • Satyandra Gupta3 

Virtual Reality volume 15, pages1–3(2011)Cite this article

  • 83 Accesses

  • Metrics details

During October 6–8 2008, Heriot-Watt Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre (IMRC) organised the 2nd International Workshop on Virtual Manufacturing (VirMan’08) as part of the EU Intuition Network Annual Conference (INTUITION2008) in Turin, Italy. This was attended by people from a wide range of internationally leading virtual manufacturing (VM) research institutes in both Europe and the USA with practitioners covering diverse areas such virtual motion capture analysis, haptic aided virtual design, collaborative virtual design environments, knowledge capture, virtual assembly planning and multimodal interfaces for design and manufacture. This work demonstrated the considerable potential and interest in VM due to the availability of lower cost technologies and applications. Research in this domain is expanding rapidly and this has been demonstrated not just by the growing number of conferences and workshops that promote VM as a theme but also the larger number of research groups investigating design and manufacturing issues which can be addressed using the intuitive interfaces associated with employing virtual reality tools.

However, the industrial uptake associated with virtual technologies and solutions is still very slow. No doubt this will expand as CAD/CAM vendors begin to see the potential for VR interfaces becoming applicable at various stages of the product engineering process. As design tools and manufacturing planning tools begin to adopt human friendly interfaces where engineers can use their intuition combined with their expertise and associated tacit knowledge, then we are sure that we will see an expansion in applications. The next stage of the process is for CAD/CAM vendors to identify and examine where current research has demonstrated potential applications for product engineering, since there are now plenty of these in the published domain, and then embed them into the appropriate parts of their systems solutions. This will be more than duplicating CAD interfaces and functionality in a 3D virtual environment but allow new and novel ways to interface with 3D engineering data using the capabilities of VR to the full as a human centric engineering tool. So the message to industry and systems developers is let us walk away from the walk-through and start looking at applying and using real, interactive, 3D interfaces to generate real engineering information, products and knowledge. The onus also falls on academic research groups to do proper comparative studies to evaluate VR solutions against existing practice; there is still a substantial lack of research being done in this area.

There are two key areas of virtual interfaces for product engineering that need focussed on in the near future. Fully interactive multi-user environments should be researched with a view to taking concurrent product design and manufacturing to new levels through fully interactive 3D web-based interfaces for team-based product design and planning. The other is complex, real-time, interactive engineering analysis, e.g. FEA for materials, statics, dynamics, fluids and thermodynamics. Once this capability is available, whole new paradigms for product engineering interfaces and knowledge capture will become possible.

Such is the interest in VM that this special issue will be published in two volumes and also includes a construction theme since there are areas of interest that cover both specialisms. Note that this editorial will be duplicated in each issue with paper-specific comments contributed based on each individual volume. Although this Special Issue addresses some of the VIRMAN’08 work, it includes papers received as a consequence of the open call issued by the VR Journal after the workshop.

Volume 1 papers

Seth, Vance and Oliver provide a seminal review of research in virtual assembly and categorise the many different approaches being researched. These vary from computer-aided assembly planning, 3D computer interactions in assembly, collision detection, physics-based modelling methods and applications and haptics to name but a few of the areas covered in this wide ranging paper. These are addressed within two main categories of application, namely constraint-based assembly and physics-based modelling. In addition to listing the benefits and challenges of virtual assembly simulation, it also offers an expanded definition of the term virtual assembly. The challenges listed in the paper include accurate collision detection, inter-part constraint detection and management, physics-based modelling, data transfer between CAD/VR systems and intuitive object manipulation in the form of force feedback. This paper gives a review of virtual assembly methods as they have evolved from the mid-1990s through to the present day, condensing a wide range of articles into an interesting summary of research over the last couple of decades and provides a useful and timely state-of-the-art study into virtual assembly.

Lee and Banerjee discuss a new paradigm for large-scale virtual manufacturing environments (LSVMEs) and discuss how there will be a need for effective data structures and collaborative techniques as they evolve and grow. This paper proposes an architecture called Metaearth for supporting LSVMEs whereby interactions amongst its virtual components can be supported and analysed. This architecture can also support reconfiguration in manufacturing simulations. The architecture also has several new features and looks promising with a case study is provided to show how this would work in practice and to illustrate the architecture’s capabilities. Discussion is then provided with regard to its limitations and potential, particularly in other domains.

In their paper, Aleotti and Caselli investigate the use of physics-based VR for task learning and disassembly planning. Although one of the most studies areas of VR in manufacturing, assembly and disassembly planning still present many challenges for the virtual manufacturing research community. Using mainly open source, a collision detection algorithm was integrated into the disassembly system which allowed colliding bodies to be simulated via hard contact constraints. Task learning experiments were then designed which demonstrated the capability for the system to self-learn the precedence relations that constitute a manufacturing task. These could then potentially be used downstream to support automated learning. A large number of follow-up trials are also described which demonstrate the capabilities of the approach for the optimisation of disassembly tasks based on precedence relations and geometric clustering. Concluding their work, they state that “…reasoning at the physical level allows the learning system to discover task similarities across multiple demonstrations.”

Liang, Chablat et al. cover a topic that will become of increasing importance in the application of immersive virtual reality systems as they are applied more generally across industry. Ergonomics and human factors will be integrated into these applications as both product and process designs begin to be generated using these technologies. In this paper, the investigation of manual drilling operations is described with a view to minimising the fatigue levels associated with a drilling task. This is based on digitally modelling endurance times and joint strengths based on a general fatigue model with associated fatigue resistances. This is successfully compared with actual experimental data to validate the approach used but more work needs to be done to make it more generic and precise. However, the methodology used and the associated validation point to how such systems in other domains can be researched and developed in the future.

Focussing on the benefits of VR in simulating a fabrication process, the work of White, Prachyabrued et al. describes a low cost real-time simulation metal inert gas (MIG) welding training system implemented on a VR platform. Simulating reality in this way will be one of the important aspects in relation to the adoption of VR in manufacturing training and simulation. Called the simulated MIG (sMIG) system, it utilises a head mounted display and welding gun for input as well as noise cues to enhance the welding experience. Using numerical heat transfer methods, they have verified the accuracy of the simulated welds against actual weld runs and have proved that it provides a realistic, interactive welding VM experience at low cost. System limitations and improvements are also identified. Future work will involve rigorous student trials to evaluate its usefulness in a real pedagogical environment.

The research work of Karkee, Steward et al. focuses on a novel architecture for the simulation and virtual prototyping of off-road vehicles utilising multi-rate simulation and multiple processors. The architecture developed comprises a dynamic solid model simulator, a 3D VR simulator and a controller and hardware interface. Individual vehicle dynamic modelling simulations are performed over a range of time steps. The real-time simulation architecture is based in Matlab/Simulink and a TCP/IP communication protocol. The system enabled the evaluation of newly developed operator-in-the-loop controllers for off-road vehicles and demonstrated its usefulness for product evaluation during the product development process.

The papers provided in this first issue give an idea of how virtual manufacturing has progressed since the first special issue on the same topic published in this journal in 2007 (Volume 11, Number 4). Many of the same issues in terms of technology developments and adoptions as well as applications research still apply. However, the number of groups participating in VM research is growing rapidly, and it is only a matter of time before the natural, intuitive, human centric interfaces associated with interactive VR design and manufacturing systems become common throughout industry.

Acknowledgments

We would like to thank all of the contributors to VirMan’08 for their stimulating contributions to the workshop and all of the authors of the papers in this issue for their hard work and patience as the final selection process took place. We feel that these contributions amply demonstrate the potential benefits that VM will bring to bear on industry when it is fully adopted. Finally, we would like to thank the editors and publishers of the Virtual Reality Journal itself for giving us the opportunity to create this Special Issue, highlighting research work in this important area of VR applications.
